Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Ultrasound-Guided Subclavian Vein Puncture Techniques

Trial_Design.evidence: Sixty patients requiring right subclavian vein catheterization were randomly assigned

Participants.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted at the Air Force Specialty Medical Center. Sixty patients requiring right subclavian vein catheterization

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to either the traditional group (n=30) or the improved group (n=30)

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare the effectiveness of an improved ultrasound-guided subclavian vein puncture technique with the traditional method

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the one-time puncture success rate, measured immediately post-procedure

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applicable due to the nature of the intervention

Number_Randomised.evidence: Sixty patients requiring right subclavian vein catheterization were randomly assigned to either the traditional group (n=30) or the improved group (n=30)

Result_Outcome.evidence: The improved group demonstrated a higher one-time puncture success rate (80% vs. 66.7%) and reduced procedure time (mean difference = 5.0334 minutes, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p < 0.001)

Harms.evidence: Complications were lower in the improved group (10% vs. 37%; p < 0.05), with fewer cases of pneumothorax and hematoma
